Award.AbstractNarration:
Number theory is a branch of mathematics with a history of over two thousand years, but it remains a vibrant subject today, linking several different mathematical fields and physics. Much recent progress in the subject has come from exploring links of number theory with geometry and algebra. This research project will study extended classifying spaces of arithmetic and analytic objects that allow degenerations, and apply the results to number theory. The project involves five graduate students in the research.

This project studies mixed Hodge structures, mixed p-adic Hodge structures, Drinfeld modules, and motives over number fields. The investigator intends to apply prior results on extended classifying spaces to the study of Iwasawa theory, the Sharifi conjectures, asymptotic behaviors of heights, regulators, and height pairings of motives over number fields, and degeneration of Hodge metrics and their p-adic Hodge versions. This research project will develop new interactions between different areas of mathematics and science, including arithmetic, physics, harmonic analysis, and representation theory. The study of extended classifying spaces of Drinfeld modules will have applications to Langlands correspondences for function fields, and degenerations of Hodge structures are related to physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Period domain such as Griffiths period domains, Shimura varieties, moduli spaces of Drinfeld modules, etc. have fruitful geometric and arithmetic applications. Griffiths period domains are moduli spaces (classifying spaces) of Hodge structures. Many Shimura varieties are moduli spaces of abelian varieties.

 It is important to have compactifications (or partial compactifications) of these period domains, which we call extended period domains. In a paper in 1970, Griffiths wrote how it is important to construct extended period domains for Griffiths period domains

 In 1988, with J. -M. Fontaine and L. Illusie, K. Kato started the theory of log structures. This is a theory which can treat degenerations nicely. Around 2000, S. Usui and K. Kato formulated the notion of log Hodge structure which is a good formulation of degenerated Hodge structure, and T. Kajiwara, K. Kato and C. Nakayama formulated the notion of log abelian variety, which is a good formulation of degenerate abelian variety. In this project, T. Fukaya, K. Kato and R. Sharifi formulated the notion of log Drinfeld module, which is a good formulation of degenerate Drinfled module.

C. Nakayama, K. Kato and S. Usui constructed the moduli spaces of log Hodge structures which are partial compactifications (which sometimes become compactifications) of moduli spaces of Hodge structures. In this project, we published a paper in which various new extended period domains are constructed (Part 4 of the series of the papers of these three members), and almost completed a paper (the Part 5) on the extended period domains associated to algebraic groups extending the theory of Mumford-Tate domains. In this project, T. Kajiwara, K. Kato, and C. Nakayama published papers on log abelian varieties (Part 5, Part 6 of series of papers) and finally completed a paper (Part 7) in which we constructed the moduli spaces of

of log abelian varieties, which give a new transparent construction of toroidal compactifications of moduli spaces of abelian varieties. This will have applications to the study of Shimura varieties. In this project, T. Fulaya, K. Kato and R. Sharifi completed a paper in which we constructed moduli spaces of log Drinfeld modules which are long-expected toroidal compactifications of moduli spaces of Drinfeld modules. This will have applications to the study of Sharifi conjectures for GL(n) of global fields of positive characteristics.

In this project, K. Kato completed a paper on the theory of height functions on Mumford-Tate domains for motives (the classifying spaces of motives, associated to algebraic groups). K. Kato proved basic results on this subject and formulated many conjectures on these height functions. This opened a new area in arithmetic geometry.

Around 2002--2010, K. Kato and T. Saito generalized the classical ramification theory to the ramification theory of algebraic varieties and of schemes. In this project, the following new progresses were obtained in the generalized ramification theory. In the papers in 2019, K. Kato and T. Saito obtained the new notion mod p Swan conductor with I. Leal, and proved the coincidence of Abbes-Saito conductor and the class field theoretic conductor of K. Kato. In a preprint in 2019, K. Kato and V. Thatte succeeded to extend the Abbes-Saito upper ramification groups of discrete valuation rings to arbitrary valuation rings.

In this project, K. Kato studied syntomic cohomology theories of $F$-crystals and formulated Tamagawa number conjecture in characteristic p by using them. The student T. Nguyen obtained non-commutative Iwasawa theory of F-crystals by using it.

In this project, K. Kato defined the \'etale cohomology, the fundamental groups, and Betti cohomology groups of non-commutative rings and generalized the theories of SGA (S\'eminaire de G\'eom\'etrie alg\'ebrique organized by Grothendieck around 1960--1970, to non-commutative rings which are finitely generated modules over their centers. This is a completely new theory. In this work, T. Fukaya and K. Kato developed the theory of L-functions for non-commutative rings.
